com.statetable.flipflop

Class DFlipFlop

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.statetable.flipflop.OneBitFlipFlop
      • com.statetable.flipflop.DFlipFlop

  • public class DFlipFlop
extends OneBitFlipFlop
    The D Flip-flop is also known as a "data" or "delay" flip-flop. It captures the value of the D-input at a definite portion of the clock cycle (such as the rising edge of the clock). That captured value becomes the Q output. At other times, the output Q does not change. The D Flip flop can be viewed as a memory cell, a zero-order hold, or a delay line.

    The DFlipFlop is an idealization of this definition in code form. It has 3 methods; namely, setCurrentState: which sets the bit to be stored in the flip-flop, getNextState: which gets the next state according to an implementing flip-flop's "rules" and current state, and setBit: which sets the current bit.

    • Method Detail

      • getNextState

        public int getNextState()
        Returns the next state of the bit stored in this flip-flop according to its rules. If D=0 this resets the next state. And if D=1, the sets the next state.
        Specified by:
        getNextState in class OneBitFlipFlop
        Returns:
        the next state of the bit stored in this flip-flop

      • setBit

        public void setBit(int bit)
        Sets the bit of this flip-flop to either 0 or 1.{0, 1}>
        Specified by:
        setBit in class OneBitFlipFlop
        Parameters:
        bit - the value to be assigned to D

      • setCurrentState

        public void setCurrentState(int currentState)
        Sets the current state of this flip-flop to some predefined value. It can only have either of 2 values, binary zero and binary one. {0, 1}>
        Specified by:
        setCurrentState in class OneBitFlipFlop
        Parameters:
        currentState - the current state of this flip-flop
